Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Experimental Determination of Non-Evaporating Film Thickness in Pool Boiling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1445946
Maroo


Boiling is used in domestic and industrial applications, ranging from residential refrigeration systems to power generation systems such as boiling water reactors. For example, about 90% of all electricity generation in the United States is by the use of steam turbines, where a large percentage of systems generate the steam using boilers. Due to its wide applicability, boiling has been researched for over five decades to understand bubble dynamics and attain enhancements in heat transfer; however, a complete knowledge of the bubble growth phenomenon is still lacking. One of the key missing pieces is the nanoscale non-evaporating liquid film (also known as the "adsorbed" film) widely theorized to exist at the base of a bubble. This film is of critical importance in bubble dynamics as it can sustain reduced/negative liquid pressure causing liquid to flow to the surface for evaporation and bubble growth. The non-evaporating film has not yet been directly measured in pool boiling experiments due to complexities associated with its nanoscale thickness and fluidic nature in the turbulent boiling process; the proposed research aims to overcome this shortcoming.

The objective of the proposed research is to perform in-situ measurements of the nanoscale non-evaporating film thickness in pool boiling through the use of a novel interdisciplinary approach: application of two independent free-space optical techniques, spectral reflectometry and Michelson-interferometry, in pool boiling experiments of water. These high resolution techniques will enable measurement of the non-evaporating film thickness and its variation during a bubble's life-cycle in the isolated bubble regime at low heat fluxes. The effect of increasing heat flux and surface temperature on the film thickness will also be investigated. The experimental determination of the non-evaporating film thickness will facilitate accurate representation of the evaporation characteristics of the microlayer (region where the film is present) and its contribution to bubble growth, compared to current numerical simulations where the film is treated as a boundary condition with an assumed constant thickness. This work can also act as a basis for enhancing pool boiling heat transfer via novel surface modifications and other techniques aimed at altering the non-evaporating film and contact line region. The proposed research will enable new course materials and lab demonstrations to give students first-hand experience in interdisciplinary visualization techniques. Undergraduate students will also be actively engaged in the proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boiling is a complex surface phenomenon involving multiple length scales (nanometers to millimeters), short time spans (cycle in milliseconds) coupled with interfacial dynamics. The region of interest lies near the heating surface where a multiscale three-phase contact line (interfacing solid and liquid with vapor) and a microlayer dictate the boiling process. However, the unsteady nature of bubble nucleation, growth and departure over a short time cycle makes it extremely challenging to visualize and analyze this region. We present a technique to create steady state vapor bubbles, which can remain stable for hours. Due to this stable nature of the bubble, we are able to perform in-situ imaging and analysis of the bubble’s three-phase contact line and microlayer allowing us to determine the upper limit of heat transfer coefficient possible in nucleate boiling. This is achieved by heating a surface that is submerged in a pool of subcooled water using a femtosecond laser. The bubble size remains stable at a constant laser power (and increases or decreases based on the laser power), thus leading to different steady-state stages of the microlayer and formation of three-phase contact line. This technique does not require the use of expensive high-speed cameras to visualize the nucleate boiling process that has traditionally been done. We believe that the technique and measurements presented in this work will enable rational design of nanostructures for boiling as well as thin-film evaporation-based thermal management of electronics.

We summarize the scientific achievements realized in this work:

a) Formation and analysis of a steady state bubble on hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces with degassed and regular (containing dissolved air) water.
b) In-situ imaging of the contact line region to measure the contact angle of a vapor bubble.
c) Analysis to determine the upper limit of heat transfer coefficient possible in nucleate boiling, obtained from experimental measurements of the microlayer.

We summarize why the outcomes of this research offer significant appeal to a popular audience:
Boiling is one of the most widely used processes to transfer heat across a surface, with applications ranging from residential sector (e.g. refrigerators) to industrial sector (e.g. boilers) to international space station (e.g. rejection of heat from system components into outer space). For example, about 90% of all electricity generation in the United States is through the use of steam turbines which require boilers. Any improvements in boiling heat transfer efficiency will result in significant energy and cost savings. For these reasons, boiling has been studied for over five decades and it has been concluded that the boiling process is highly determined on the dynamics of the smallest length-scale regions present in a vapor bubble, i.e. the multi-scale microlayer and three-phase contact line. Surprisingly, fundamental understanding and in-situ visualization of these regions has been lacking, and advancements in these areas are desired. Through this work, knowledge attained on the permissible ranges of width and maximum heat transfer coefficient in the evaporating region present in the microlayer will:

a) enable design of nanostructures to optimize the width of microlayer and achieve desired transfer of heat with boiling.
b) assist is understanding boiling in outer space where lack of gravity causes bubbles to stay stationary on the heated surface, similar to our work.
c) advance the next-generation technology of thermal management of electronics based on thin-film evaporation of microlayer from micro-menisci.
